'''Rideshare advertising''' is a form of digital, [[out-of-home advertising]] that uses in-car advertisements in [[peer-to-peer ridesharing|ridesharing]] vehicles.<ref name="adweek">{{cite web | url=http://www.adweek.com/news/technology/startup-plans-sell-advertising-uber-and-lyft-cars-164044 | title=This Startup Plans to Sell Advertising in Uber and Lyft Cars | publisher=Adweek.com | date=April 14, 2015 | accessdate=July 16, 2015 | author=Johnson, Lauren}}</ref><ref name=ForbesVideoAds>{{cite news|last1=Caompbell|first1=Harry|title=Video Ads Are Coming To The Back Of Your Uber|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/harrycampbell/2015/03/31/video-ads-are-coming-to-the-back-of-your-uber/|accessdate=16 July 2015|publisher=Forbes|date=31 March 2015}}</ref>
==Technology==
Rideshare advertising is performed through digital display screens in the backseat of rideshare vehicles. Drivers contract with rideshare advertising companies and ad displays are controlled by the company.<ref name=ForbesVideoAds/> James Bellefeuille, founder of [[Vugo (company)|Vugo]], coined the term "Rideshare Advertising".<ref name="ForbesVideoAds" />
==Reception==
Drivers expressed support for the new opportunity to earn additional income.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/uber-drivers-can-now-accept-tips-electronically-without-ubers-help/|title=Uber drivers can now accept tips electronically, without Uber's help|access-date=2016-08-23}}</ref> Some rideshare companies such as Uber disapprove of rideshare advertising of companies including [[Vugo (company)|Vugo]], claiming that it does not add to the value of passenger experience.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.betaboston.com/news/2015/06/01/startups-aim-to-put-video-ads-in-ride-sharing-cars/ | title=Startups aim to put video ads in ride-sharing cars | publisher=Boston Globe | date=June 1, 2015 | accessdate=July 16, 2015 | author=Woodward, Curt}}</ref> Uber has recommended that drivers do not participate in rideshare advertising, but stated that they recommend so as employees advising other employees due to drivers being independent contractors and not employees of the company.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/uber-discourages-drivers-from-using-viewswagen-2015-5 | title=Uber says it will 'discourage' its drivers from earning extra cash by placing ads in their cars | publisher=Business Insider | date=May 11, 2015 | accessdate=July 16, 2015 | author=O'Reilly, Lara}}</ref>

Time for [[WP:TNT]]?|date=July 2016}} {{notability|Companies|date=July 2016}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Squirrel Systems Ltd. | type = Private | logo = Squirrel Systems.png | foundation = 1984 | location = [[Burnaby]], [[British Columbia]] | products = Squirrel Professional, Squirrel in a Box, Squirrel in a Box for Hotels | industry = [[Hospitality]] Systems, [[Computer hardware]] | homepage = [http://www.squirrelsystems.com www.squirrelsystems.com] }}
'''Squirrel Systems''' is a [[Burnaby]]-based [[point of sale]] vendor specializing in [[hospitality]] management systems. Squirrel is based in Burnaby, [[Canada]].<ref name="expansion">{{cite press release |title = Squirrel Systems Accommodates Expansion with New Head Office Location |publisher = Squirrel Systems |date = 2005-11-22 |url = http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/20051122NewHOLocation.htm |accessdate = 2010-11-03 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101129211537/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/20051122NewHOLocation.htm |archivedate = 2010-11-29 |df = }}</ref>
==History== Squirrel Systems was founded in 1984, and released the first restaurant point of sale system to use an integrated diskless [[touchscreen]] terminal for order management.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Originally a wholly owned [[subsidiary]] of Sulcus Hospitality Technologies Corporation, in 1998 Sulcus merged with Eltrax Systems, Incorporated ([[Nasdaq]] SmallCap: ELTX).<ref name="eltrax">{{cite press release |title = Sulcus announces planned merger with Eltrax Systems, Inc. |publisher = Eltrax Systems |date = 1998-11-12 |url = http://www.squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19981112SulcusEltraxMerger.htm |accessdate = 2010-11-03 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101129204144/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19981112SulcusEltraxMerger.htm |archivedate = 2010-11-29 |df = }}</ref> Squirrel is currently a wholly owned subsidiary of Marin Investments Ltd.<ref name="marin">{{cite press release |title = Squirrel Systems Appoints New President |publisher = Squirrel Systems & Marin Investments Limited |date = May 2008 |url = http://www.squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/2008-01-07PRSquirrelPresident.htm |accessdate = 2010-11-03 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101129200811/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/2008-01-07PRSquirrelPresident.htm |archivedate = 2010-11-29 |df = }}</ref>
==Squirrel Workstation== One of the unique characteristics of Squirrel's original product was the use of hardened [[liquid crystal display|LCD]] touchscreen terminals. Unlike other systems that used keyboards and [[cathode ray tube|CRT monitors]], Squirrel terminals had no moving parts and were easily adapted to any operating environment. The original Squirrel terminals reached over 35,000 installed units worldwide, and was the first to integrate an LCD panel, credit card reader, employee ID reader, and [[central processing unit|CPU]] inside a single unit.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Later units would incorporate IP connectivity, remote booting of a customized [[Linux]] operating system, and a [[Java virtual machine]].<ref name="WS7">{{cite press release |title=Squirrel Announces New Network-Ready Touch Terminal |publisher=Squirrel Systems |date=1999-06-21 |url=http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19990621NetworkReadyTerminal.htm |accessdate=2010-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129205121/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19990621NetworkReadyTerminal.htm |archivedate=2010-11-29 |df= }}{{better source|date=July 2016}}</ref>
==Squirrel Embedded Linux== In 1998 Squirrel Systems released ''Squirrel Embedded Linux'' (''SEL''), a customized distribution of Linux for "thin client" terminal architecture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/4798 |title=Squirrel POS |publisher=[[Linux Journal]] |date=2001-09-01 |accessdate=2009-07-17}}</ref> ''SEL'' has several characteristics that were unique at the time of development, including primary support for [[diskless workstation]]s, customized high-volume touchscreen drivers, integrated Java virtual machine with hardware control, and two-stage booting from a Windows server.<ref name="linux2">{{cite web |title=Embedded Linux advantages – and challenges – in a retail POS system |url=http://linuxdevices.com/articles/AT2874315267.html |accessdate=2007-03-30 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130127205834/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.linuxfordevices.com%2Fc%2Fa%2FLinux-For-Devices-Articles%2FEmbedded-Linux-advantages-and-challenges-in-a-retail-POS-system%2F |archivedate=2013-01-27 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> <ref name="linux">{{cite press release |title=Eltrax Announces Release Of Linux Version Of Restaurant Application Solution. |publisher=Eltrax Systems |date=1999-12-20 |url=http://www.squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19991220PREltraxAnnouncementLinux.htm |accessdate=2010-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129205453/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19991220PREltraxAnnouncementLinux.htm |archivedate=2010-11-29 |df= }}</ref>
==Industry awards== {{unreferenced section|date=July 2016}} * In 2010, [[O'Charley's]] named Squirrel as its Enterprise Support Partner of the Year at the annual Inukshuk Business Partner Awards.<ref name="ocharleys">{{cite web |title=O'Charley's honors partners |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3190/is_9_44/ai_n53519444/ | publisher = [[Nation's Restaurant News]] |accessdate=2010-11-03}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=July 2016}} * Squirrel Systems was awarded the 2009 [[Epson]] Envision Award for Innovation for its Squirrel in a Box product.<ref name="epson">{{cite press release |title=Squirrel in a Box Solution Receives Top Honors at Epson Annual Partner Conference |publisher=Squirrel Systems & [[Epson]] |date=March 2009 |url=http://www.squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/PREpsonInnovationAward33109.htm |accessdate=2010-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129200834/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/PREpsonInnovationAward33109.htm |archivedate=2010-11-29 |df= }}</ref> * Squirrel Systems was awarded the 1999 Independent Cash Register Dealers Association Silver Award for Outstanding Sponsor in Systems/Software.<ref name="ircda">{{cite press release |title=Squirrel Wins Silver at I.C.R.D.A. Convention |publisher=Squirrel Systems |date=1999-07-29 |url=http://www.squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19990729SquirrelWinsSilver.htm |accessdate=2010-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129211831/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/19990729SquirrelWinsSilver.htm |archivedate=2010-11-29 |df= }}</ref> * In 1998, Squirrel was the third recipient of the Microsoft Retail Application Developer award at the HITEC Show in Los Angeles. Microsoft recognized SquirrelONE as the first application to integrate [[Java (Sun)|Java]], [[Microsoft SQL Server]], and [[Windows NT]] in the retail market.<ref name="RAD">{{cite press release |title=Squirrel WINS MICROSOFT 1998 R.A.D. AWARD |publisher=Squirrel Systems & [[Microsoft]] |date=1998-06-16 |url=http://www.squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/PRMicrosoftRADAward.htm |accessdate=2010-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129204232/http://squirrelsystems.com/about-squirrel-systems/News/PRMicrosoftRADAward.htm |archivedate=2010-11-29 |df= }}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} [[File:Rainbow Trout Swimbait.JPG|thumb|Rainbow trout-like swimbait, with a paddle tail.]]
'''Swimbaits''' are a loosely defined class of [[fishing lure]]s that imitate fish and tend to be distinct in design from a typical [[crankbait]].<ref>http://adventure.howstuffworks.com/outdoor-activities/fishing/freshwater-tips/bass/bass-fishing-swimbaits1.htm</ref>
Swimbaits are usually different from crankbaits by the way they generate lure action. Some are rubber "paddle tail" lures that appear to swim when the tail flutters during retrieve. Some are jointed baits that wave like a flag in the water when retrieved, without any obvious mechanism to generate motion. Some are large jointed crankbaits or crankbait/plastic lure hybrids.
Swimbaits originated as lures designed to imitate the planted [[rainbow trout]] in [[Southern California]] [[reservoir]]s that [[Largemouth bass|Largemouth Bass]] and [[Striped bass|Striped Bass]] fed on. They were larger and more lifelike imitations than most available mass-produced lures.
The term swimbait is often used to indicate plastic "paddle tail" lures, regardless of size or appearance.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox website | name = Techdirt | logo = Techdirt logo.png | logo_size = 240px | screenshot = | caption = | url = [https://techdirt.com/ techdirt.com] | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 24,272 ({{as of|2016|9|29|alt=September 2016}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/techdirt.com |title=Techdirt.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2016-09-29 }}</ref> | commercial = Yes | type = | registration = Optional | owner = Floor64, Inc. | author = [[Mike Masnick]] | editor = Mike Masnick | launch date = 1997 | current status = Active | revenue = }}
'''Techdirt''' is an internet [[blog]] that reports on technology's legal challenges and related business and [[economic policy]] issues, in context of the [[digital revolution]]. It focusses on [[intellectual property]], [[patent]], [[information privacy]] and [[copyright reform]] in particular.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/02/18/open_and_shut/|title=John Lennon's lesson for public-domain innovation - IP protection hurting, not helping, US and UK|date=18 Feb 2013|author=Matt Asay |accessdate=2017-01-02|quote=TechDirt highlights research showing that extending copyrights increases prices and limits dissemination of knowledge, while also pointing out that people who believe patents cause innovation are simply confusing correlation with causation. If anything, patents inhibit innovation.|publisher=[[The Register]]}}</ref>
== Description == The website Masnick founded in 1997 was originally based on the [[weblog]] software [[Slash (CMS)|Slash]]. Techblog's content is based on reader submissions as well as the editorial staff's picks. The website makes use of [[MySQL]], [[Apache HTTP Server|Apache]], and [[PHP]], and is hosted at ActionWeb.<ref name="about">{{cite web|title=About Techdirt|url=https://www.techdirt.com/about.php |publisher=Techdirt |accessdate=December 13, 2011}}</ref>
There is a guest editor section in techdirt, called "Favorite Techdirt Posts of the Week", where several high-profile personalities of politics and culture contributed articles over the years; for instance [[Marietje Schaake]], [[European Parliament]] MEP for the [[Netherlands]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Schaake|first=Marietje|title=European Parliament Member Marietje Schaake's Favorite Techdirt Posts Of The Week|url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20120518/14001518975/european-parliament-member-marietje-schaakes-favorite-techdirt-posts-week.shtml|publisher=techdirt|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref> Sen. [[Ron Wyden]] of [[Oregon]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Wyden|first=Ron|title=Senator Ron Wyden's Favorite Techdirt Posts Of The Week|url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20120127/17433217576/senator-ron-wydens-favorite-techdirt-posts-week.shtml|publisher=techdirt|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref> or author [[Glyn Moody]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Moody|first=Glyn|title=Glyn Moody's Favorite Techdirt Posts Of The Week |url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20110422/12175514003/glyn-moodys-favorite-techdirt-posts-week.shtml |publisher=techdirt |accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref>
== Reception and impact == [[File:Mike Masnick (7997226136) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Techdirt founder Mike Masnick in 2012]] On Techdirt in January 2005 the "[[Streisand effect]]" was coined by founder [[Mike Masnick]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techdirt.com/articles/20060713/0332234.shtml|title=Is Leveraging the Streisand Effect Illegal? |publisher=techdirt.com |date=July 13, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=87809195|title=The Streisand Effect' Snags Effort to Hide Documents |publisher=[[NPR|National Public Radio]]|work=[[All Things Considered]]|date=February 29, 2008 |author=Robert Siegel |quote=The episode is the latest example of a phenomenon known as the "Streisand Effect." Robert Siegel talks with Mike Masnick, CEO of Techdirt Inc., who coined the term.}}</ref>
In 2003 [[Forbes Magazine|Forbes]] named techdirt as one of the "Best Tech Blogs".<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/2003/03/14/cx_ah_0314blog.html "Best Tech Blogs"] on [[Forbes]] by Arik Hesseldahl (3/14/2003)</ref> In 2006 techdirt has been praised for its "sharp, pithy analysis of current tech issues" by [[Bloomberg Businessweek]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Hof |first=Rob |title=The Dirt on Techdirt's New Blogger Community |url=http://www.businessweek.com/the_thread/techbeat/archives/2006/10/the_dirt_on_techdirts_new_blogger_community.html |accessdate=December 13, 2011 |newspaper=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=October 11, 2006}}</ref> In 2007 techdirt was nominated for the [[Webby Award]] in the section "Web Blog - Business".<ref>[http://webbyawards.com/winners/2007/web/general-website/blog-business/techdirt/ techdirt] on webbyawards.com (2007)</ref> Techdirt has been named among the favorite blogs of ''[[PC Magazine]]'' in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|last=Heater |first=Brian |last2=Griffith |first2=Eric|title=Our Favorite Blogs|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2337388,00.asp |publisher=[[PC Magazine]] |accessdate=December 13, 2011 |date=December 29, 2008}}</ref> In 2015 techdirt was positively mentioned for the bold step to allow readers to remove [[web ads]].<ref>[http://digiday.com/publishers/fight-one-tech-publication-letting-readers-remove-ads/ Why fight it?': One tech publication is letting readers remove ads] by Ricardo Bilton on digiday (October 2, 2015)</ref>
In 2009, English singer [[Lily Allen]] created a blog critical of [[music piracy]] where she [[plagiarized]] an entire post from Techdirt.<ref>{{cite news|last=Masnick|first=Mike|title=Lily Allen: Copying Isn't Alright... Unless It's Done By Lily Allen|url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20090921/0527456270.shtml|accessdate=December 13, 2011|newspaper=Techdirt|date=September 21, 2009}}</ref> Following an exchange with Techdirt, debating hypocrisy in the musician's handling of [[copyright infringement]], Allen shut down her blog.<ref>{{cite news |last=Chivers |first=Tom |title=Lily Allen drops fight against filesharing after Techdirt spat |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/6226690/Lily-Allen-drops-fight-against-filesharing-after-Techdirt-spat.html |accessdate=December 13, 2011 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date=September 24, 2009}}</ref>
[[Marvin Ammori]], a lawyer who advocates on [[network neutrality]] and [[Internet censorship|Internet freedom]] issues, praised techdirt in the 2011s [[Stop Online Piracy Act]] controversy with: "I’m not sure anyone did more to educate the public about SOPA than Techdirt."<ref>[https://medium.com/thoughts-on-journalism/how-this-blogger-became-one-of-the-most-influential-voices-in-tech-policy-a80c0c495839#.gf8d56kha How this blogger became one of the most influential voices in tech policy] on [[medium.com]] by Simon Owens (Jan 21, 2016)</ref>
==Shiva Ayyadurai lawsuit== In 2017, [[Shiva Ayyadurai]] filed suit against Techdirt for defamation in response to a series of articles critical of Ayyadurai's claims to have invented [[email]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Man who says he invented e-mail sues Techdirt for disputing claim |publisher=[[Ars Technica]] |date=6 January 2017 |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/01/man-who-says-he-invented-e-mail-sues-techdirt-for-disputing-claim/ |first=David |last=Kravets}}</ref> Techdirt announced its intention to fight the suit, describing it as a "[[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] fight for its life".<ref>{{cite news |title=Techdirt's First Amendment fight for its life |url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20170111/11440836465/techdirts-first-amendment-fight-life.shtml |publisher=Techdirt |first=Mike |last=Masnick |date=11 January 2017}}</ref> A federal judge dismissed the defamation claims on September 6, 2017.<ref>{{cite news |title=Techdirt prevails in libel lawsuit over e-mail invention claims |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/09/judge-dismisses-libel-lawsuit-filed-by-self-proclaimed-e-mail-inventor/ |publisher=Ars Technica |first=Cyrus |last=Farivar |date=6 September 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{More footnotes|date=February 2016}} '''Technology doping''' is a new term that has been becoming more popular recently in [[sport]]s. Technology doping is the practice of gaining a competitive advantage using sports equipment. The [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] (WADA) considers prohibiting technologies if they are "performance-enhancing" or "being against the spirit of the sport". In 2006, WADA initiated a consultation on technology doping which is now officially recognised as a threat, whilst the decision to allow or ban a new technology, specifically relating to sports equipment, is the responsibility of each sport’s own governing body.<ref name=sportseng>{{cite web|title=Sports Engineering: An Unfair Advantage?|url=http://www.imeche.org/Libraries/2011_Press_Releases/Sports_Engineering_report_FINAL_1.sflb.ashx|publisher=Institution of Mechanical Engineers|page=15|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref>
== Grey area == Since most sports require equipment of some sort, it can be tricky to determine what is technology doping and what is not. The [[Sports governing body|governing authorities]] of different sports usually make judgment calls about the technological advances in their sport’s equipment. Technological advancements are often allowed unless the governing authorities feel they threaten the integrity of the sport. A report released immediately before the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] quotes an extensive public survey that shows that people fear that sports engineering could: overshadow the triumph of human spirit and effort, make certain sports easier, create unfairness so the "best athletes" might not win, and ensure that rich athletes and countries have an advantage over the poor ones.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hsu|first=Jeremy|title=Are Humans or Technology Breaking Olympic Records?|url=http://www.innovationnewsdaily.com/1484-humans-technology-olympic-records.html|publisher=InnovationNewsDail|accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref>
==Examples ==
=== LZR racer swimsuit === The [[LZR Racer]] has been one of the most discussed technologies accused of being technology doping. The LZR Racer bodysuit by [[Speedo]] is a high-performance swimsuit. It is made with a material that was designed to mimic shark skin. The suit allows for better oxygen flow to the muscles, holds the body in a more [[hydrodynamic]] position, and traps air which adds buoyancy.
At the [[2008 Beijing Olympics]], this suit was worn by many swimmers. In fact, some swimmers wore two or more of these suits at once to increase buoyancy. In total, 23 out of the 25 swimming world records broken at the Beijing Olympics were broken by swimmers wearing this suit.
Some people thought these suits might be so technologically advanced that using them in competition was essentially technology doping. After the Beijing Olympics and subsequent swimming events, at which many world records were broken by swimmers wearing the LZR suit, [[FINA]] (Fédération Internationale de Natation) banned all body-length swimsuits. Men's suits could only maximally cover from the waist to the knee. Women's suits could only cover from shoulder to knee. They also stipulated that the fabric used to make the suits must be a “textile” and the suit could not have fastening devices, such as zippers. These new rules took effect in January 2010.
=== Ionized shirts ===
A New Zealand firm has created “IonX shirts” which are made of a material that claims to contain a negatively charged electromagnetic field. It further claims that the shirt helps increase blood flow, which in turn helps deliver more oxygen to the muscles and remove lactic acid from the muscles more quickly. For the moment, this technology is still legal. The [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] has ruled that since there is no scientific publication that confirms the material actually changes the body’s ion charges or enhances performance and also the material does not contain prohibited substances, this technology is not banned as of now.
=== Interactive materials ===
Researchers at the [[Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation]], an Australian science agency, created a garment that can monitor movement and give feedback. For example, a basketball player can wear the material in the form of a sleeve. Then sensors in the material send information to a computer when the player takes shots and responds with audible tones. The material essentially gives the athlete real-time feedback on their movements. Athletes can learn patterns of tones that indicate successful or unsuccessful movements and use these to make improvements. The material helps correct the athlete’s movement and helps the athlete gain [[muscle memory]] so they can continue to perform well once the material is taken away.
=== Mechanical doping === {{main|Mechanical doping}}
In [[cycling]], mechanical doping is the use of a secret [[motor]] to propel the bicycle. It is banned by the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]]. One of the first allegations of mechanical doping was in the [[2010 Tour of Flanders]]. The first confirmed use of mechanical doping was at the [[2016 UCI Cyclo-cross World Championships]]. Bike inspections have become commonplace in road racing since the 2015 season. Riders found guilty of mechanical doping are subject to a fine ranging from 20,000 to 200,000 Swiss Francs and a suspension of at least six months.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/cycling/35452791|title=UCI confirms motorised bike at Cyclo-cross World Championships|last=|first=|date=January 31, 2016|website=BBC|publisher=|access-date=October 25, 2016}}</ref> In the [[2016 Tour de France]], French officials utilized thermal cameras to enforce their policy against mechanical doping.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/tour-de-france-thermal-cameras-detect-mechanical-doping/story?id=40158791|title=Tour de France to Use Thermal Cameras to Detect Mechanical Doping|last=Thorbecke|first=Catherine|date=June 27, 2016|website=ABC News|publisher=|access-date=October 25, 2016}}</ref>
=== Artificial limbs ===
Amputees can compete in the [[Paralympic Games]] using artificial limbs. There has been significant [[Oscar Pistorius#Dispute over prosthetics|debate]] on whether the artificial limbs confer an advantage over able-bodied athletes and whether athletes using them can participate in the [[Olympic Games]]. There has also been debate on the effect of the length of the artificial limbs in the Paralympic Games.
== Standardized equipment ==
Many sports set standards for equipment, to prevent unfair advantages between competitors. This often involves the types of materials the equipment is made from or dimensions/sizes. For example, [[tennis]] racquets must not exceed the maximum length and width limits. Soccer balls must not exceed weight limits. [[Golf clubs]] must fit shape regulations.
==See also== *[[Doping at the Asian Games]] *[[Doping at the Commonwealth Games]] *[[Doping at the Olympics]]

[[File:W3ra logo.gif|right]] The '''World Reuse, Repair and Recycling Association''' (WR3A) is a business [[consortium]] dedicated to the reform of the trade of [[e-waste]]. The WR3A is inspired by [[fair trade]] organizations.
==History== WR3A is a Fair Trade association (tradename Fair Trade Recycling reserved in 2013) established both to improve the export markets for surplus electronics and e-waste, and to defend them from biased reporting and racial profiling. WR3A was conceived in 2006 following a visit to China by a group including a USA electronics recycler (American Retroworks Inc.), a University of California Davis recycling program director, and a Seattle recycler with a zero-export policy.
The group was inspired by a visit to three of China's semi knock down factories. Those factories purchased USA computer monitors which still have functional [[Cathode ray tube|CRTs]]. The CRTs are knocked down to the bare tube, which is inserted into a new TV or monitor case, complete with new tuner board, etc. WR3A founders observed that Western journalists reporting on the purchase and import of the used CRTs invariably described them as "primitive" wire burning operations, rather than re-manufacturers. These were often the same contract manufacturers who originally assembled brand new CRT monitors, and now rebuilt second-hand CRTs. The USA has its own CRT refurbishing factory, Video Display Corp of Tucker, Georgia.<ref>http://www.videodisplay.com</ref>
WR3A proposed to form a coalition of USA companies to export only functional CRT monitors directly to the reuse factories, removing imploded, damaged, screen-burned, older, or non-compliant raster (e.g. Trinitron) CRTs from loads destined for CRT factories.<ref>Recycling Today, February 2005</ref> The USA companies which remove and recycle the bad 1/3 of CRTs would benefit from higher prices, and the Chinese factories would bypass the sorting villages such as Guiyu. The WR3A was swamped by orders from Asian factories that year.<ref>http://recyclingtoday.texterity.com/recyclingtoday/200504/?pg=44</ref>
The Chinese government, which took over most of the new CRT manufacturing capacity worldwide in the 1990s,<ref>The Economist, February 25, 1989</ref> eventually opposed the import of used CRTs. Many of the SKD factory owners relocated their businesses to countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. Others relocated their used monitor sourcing operations only to Hong Kong and Vietnam, trucking the CRTs overland to Chinese factories.
During this period, several anti-globalist NGOs began a campaign to end trade in used electronics, especially CRTs. CBS 60 Minutes, The Economist, BusinessWeek and others ran reports claiming that 80% of the displays exported were not reused but burned for copper in primitive scrapyards. The source of the 80% dumping claim later retracted it<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://retroworks.blogspot.com/2013/05/basel-action-network-explains-80-or.html|title=Good Point: Ethical Electronics, Recycling "e-Waste" Blog: Basel Action Network Explains the 80%, or 90%, 75% or 50% "DATA"|last=Ingenthron|first=Robin|website=Good Point|access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref>.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2013-05-26/stop-the-baseless-panicking-over-u-s-e-waste#disqus_thread|title=Terms of Service Violation|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref>
Eventually, reuse operations in Asia turned to re-export to Africa, and used local sources (urban Asian cities) for used CRTs used in remanufacturing new TV and monitor displays. With the decline of purchases of used displays from the USA in 2011, WR3A recognized organizational conflicts between cooperative suppliers competing for a declining market. The organization refined its mission in 2013 emphasize "anti-defamation" of overseas refurbishing companies, and promoted used electronics exports through peer-reviewed fair trade agreements. Importers of used equipment in Africa, Asia and Latin America consider the organization a defender of Tech Sector refurbishers. WR3A remains dedicated to the principle that if used computer exports are outlawed, only outlaws will export used computers. <ref>http://chicagoheights.patch.com/groups/business-news/p/the-laws-stigmas-and-truths-about-exporting-electronic-waste</ref> The organization strongly refutes what it considers racial profiling of tech sector in emerging markets.
The organization has members in South America, Africa, Asia, North America, and Europe, dedicated to defending legitimate used electronics exporters from what the organization considers false and defamatory declarations as "e-waste" and "toxics externalization".
==Recent activities== In 2015, 2017, and 2018 WR3A led visits to the [[Agbogbloshie]] District in central Accra, bringing journalists from [http://interactive.aljazeera.com/aje/2015/ewaste/index.html Al Jazeera], The Independent, [http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/burning-truth-behind-e-waste-dump-africa-180957597/?no-ist Smithsonian], and others to meet with Dagbani speaking translators. The visit led the journalists to discredit<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ingenthron |first1=Robin |title=Reuse Advocate calls Agbogbloshie 'a hoax' |url=https://resource-recycling.com/e-scrap/2015/04/30/reuse-advocate-calls-agbogbloshie-a-hoax/ |website=E-Scrap News |publisher=Resource Recycling |accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> allegations that Agbogbloshie was "the largest e-waste dump in the world", a "former wetland on the outskirts of the city", and that it received hundreds of sea containers full of junk electronics. WR3A found credible evidence that dumping at the site was being exaggerated by Accra Metropolitan Association representatives interested in relocating economic refugees to develop the property, three months [https://discardstudies.com/2015/06/23/sweeping-away-agbogbloshie-again/ before forced evictions]. Used electronics processed at the site were shown to be delivered by carters with wheelbarrows, and to consist of devices, such as VCRs, which had been imported decades previously. WR3A provided reporters with World Bank statistics showing domestic Ghana generation more than accounted for the e-waste observed in Ghana, and recorded the organization's own interviews of Ghana Tech Sector representatives (uploaded to Youtube / WR3A).
[[File:FTR IntlBoys LogobyRobinIngenthron.jpg|thumb|Fair Trade Recycling registered trademark licensed to WR3A]] In September 2013, the WR3A adapted the tradename "Fair Trade Recycling". The trademark was registered with the USPTO and registered as a supplemental certification on May 26, 2015. The organization does not claim to be recognized by "fairtrade" (one word).
In April 2013, WR3A held a "Fair Trade Recycling Summit"<ref>http://www.free-press-release.com/news-fair-trade-recycling-summit-tackles-international-e-waste-1362666552.html</ref> at Middlebury College in Vermont.<ref>http://fairtraderecycling.org/</ref> The Summit brought together researchers from Memorial University (Canada), Pontificia Universidad Catholica de Peru, University of Southern California (USA), Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), representatives of the USA International Trade Office, Basel Convention Secretariat, Interpol, and several used electronics importers from Africa, Asia, and Latin America. The group deliberated on beneficial development in emerging markets through electronics reuse and repair (labelled "Tinkerer's Blessing" after Yuzo Takahashi's 2000 technology history, A Network of Tinkerers.<ref>Yuzo Takahashi's 2000 technology history, A Network of Tinkerers: The Advent of the Radio and Television Receiver Industry in Japan</ref>). The role of electronics repair and reverse engineering in development was contrasted with the so-called "Resource Curse" of economic development through natural resource exploitation. Middlebury students and presenters discussed whether a more balanced approach to recycling secondary materials may be warranted. A follow up meeting between WR3A and Interpol was held in July 2013.<ref>http://retroworks.blogspot.com/2013/07/bullyboy-iii-meet-real-environmental.html</ref> In November, 2013, Interpol announced a new research program to study the used electronics trade before continuing arrests of African importers (Project Eden).<ref>http://www.edenproject.com/sites/default/files/waste-neutral-framework-project-report.pdf</ref>
The debate between Fair Trade Recycling advocates and the anti-export organization Basel Action Network was profiled in USA Today (September 26, 2013),<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/09/26/e-waste-empire-middlebury-vermont-discarded-electronics/2880359/</ref> in Discovery Magazine, and in NIH in 2006<ref>https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.n.ethz.ch%2F~schmia%2Fdownload%2Fcited_papers%2FUnfair%2520Trade%2520e-Waste%2520in%2520Africa.pdf</ref>
In July 2012, Memorial University of Newfoundland, Canada, announced a 5-year research project to study and map the routes of used electronics, WEEE, and "e-waste" exports.<ref>https://www.mun.ca/geog/research/digital_develop.php</ref> WR3A is a partner in the research grant, along with researchers from universities in Peru and California. The first year, the group will document efforts to develop a "Fair Trade Recycling" model in Mexico (see NPR, PBS, AP, coverage<ref>Links to stories by PRI, NPR, PBS, AP at http://retroworks.net/retroworksofmexico.html</ref>), and then research the possible application of the model to Peru, Bangladesh, and China.
WR3A formerly adapted and registered the tradename "Fair Trade Recycling" in 2012.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
WR3A collaborated with Massachusetts Institute of Technology for publication of MIT's January 2012 study on E-waste generation and exports. WR3A provided researchers with detailed reconciliations of 3 years of exports from WR3A members. MIT compared WR3A data to corroborating data from ISRI, USEPA, Basel Secretariat (Ghana, Nigeria) studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/11M0QC3wcXNEf4eyW0eO2rOeAArciFKWQGXFEeJGqDP74FaL_8bADG7eeoD8K/edit?usp=sharing |title=Characterizing Transboundary Flows of Used Electronics: Summary Report |author1=T. Reed Miller |author2=Jeremy Gregory |author3=Huabo Duan |author4=Randolph Kirchain |publisher=[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] |date=January 2012 |format=pdf |accessdate=20 March 2013}}</ref>
In May 2011, WR3A was interviewed as part of an "e-waste" by German news magazine ZDF.Kultur, which investigated the assumptions that African imports were "primitive" and linked exports to Egypt's Green Revolution.<ref>http://vimeo.com/53719841</ref>
In March, 2011. WR3A was profiled in Motherboard.tv, for the organization's case that reduced exports of used electronics by "stewards" was having unintended consequences.<ref>http://www.motherboard.tv/2011/3/26/e-waste-recycling-exports-are-good</ref>
In October, 2010, WR3A announced a partnership with Basel Action Network to reduce unnecessary breakage and destruction of working computer monitors in California, under California SB20 laws. This followed a report critical of California "cancellation" policies published in the [[Sacramento Bee]] on July 19, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacbee.com/2010/07/18/2897620/mexican-town-turns-us-e-waste.html|title=Mexican Town Turns U.S. E-Waste into Treasure|publisher=sacbee.com|date=2010-07-18}}</ref>
On July 30, 2010, Discovery News presented an analysis contrasting WR3A's "fair trade" engagement approach with the [[Basel Action Network]]'s (BAN) "trade restriction" approach, and abstained from choosing sides.,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.discovery.com/tech/revenge-of-the-tv-monitor-zombies.html |title=Revenge of the TV Monitor Zombies |date=30 July 2010 |publisher=[[Discovery Communications]] |accessdate=25 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.discovery.com/news_tech_nfpc/2010/07/revenge-of-the-tv-monitor-zombies.html |title=(Discovery Blog record) |date=30 July 2010 |publisher=[[Discovery Communications]] |accessdate=25 September 2010}}</ref>
On May 15, 2009, [[National Public Radio]]'s (NPR) program ''Living On Earth'' profiled one of WR3A's members - a women's [[cooperative]] doing TV repair and recycling in Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.loe.org/shows/shows.htm?programID=09-P13-00020#feature7|title=On Their Own Terms|format=NPR Transcript|date=2009-05-15|accessdate=2009-07-01}}</ref>
In January 2009, the organization presented statistics and a film at the Keynote Address of the CES 2009 in Las Vegas.<ref>[http://vidego.multicastmedia.com/player.php?v=ejo772li Video of CES 2009 Keynote Address] broken link?</ref> The statistics demonstrated that the rate of growth of internet access is much higher in countries with very low incomes. It is logically unlikely that this growth can be achieved with new computers. The WR3A also presented film of the reuse and refurbishing operations which demonstrate proper recycling practices and best available practices in these ten countries.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ldXFgSz0AFU WR3A film]</ref>
The WR3A was contracted as a consultant to the US [[Environmental Protection Agency]] for its July 2008 publication ''Electronic Waste Management in the United States''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/osw/conserve/materials/ecycling/docs/app-1.pdf|title=Waste Management in the United States|format=pdf|publisher=Office of Solid Waste, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency|date=July 2008|accessdate=2009-07-01}}</ref>

Global|website=www.caixinglobal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-07}} He is China's 11th richest person and 118th in the world. Xiaomi is the world's 4th most valuable technology start-up after receiving US$1.1 billion funding from investors, making Xiaomi's valuation more than US$46 billion.{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/xiaomi-raises-another-11-billion-to-become-most-valuable-tech-start-up-2014-12-29 |title=Xiaomi raises another $1.1 billion to become most-valuable tech start-up |date=29 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303201448/http://www.marketwatch.com/story/xiaomi-raises-another-11-billion-to-become-most-valuable-tech-start-up-2014-12-29 |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }} ==History of Xiaomi== {{Main|History of Xiaomi}} ==Products== {{Main|Products of Xiaomi}} Xiaomi produces many products. Notably, it produces smartphones which run on their own version of [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[MIUI]] firmware. Observers suggest that part of Xiaomi's rapid success rests on its ability to differentiate itself within the Android universe.{{Cite book|title= Corporate China 2.0: The Great Shakeup|last= Liu|first= Qiao|publisher= Palgrave Macmillan|year= 2016|isbn= 9781137603722|location= New York|pages= 205 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1NPJDQAAQBAJ}}{{qn|date=August 2018}} The company has increased its range of products; its smartphones include: Mi Series, [[Xiaomi Mi Note|Mi Note Series]], [[Xiaomi Mi Max|Mi Max Series]], [[Xiaomi Mi MIX|Mi Mix Series]] and the [[Xiaomi Redmi|Redmi Series]]. As well as mobile phones, Xiaomi has started selling [[Wearable computer| wearables]], mobile accessories, and appliances such as [[Smart TV|television]] and speakers. In 2018 it was selling tablets, laptops, and [[smart-home]] devices. Xiaomi operates on a [[vertically-integrated]] model that enables the company to sell hardware at cost or below in order to attract users and earn money by selling content. [[Hugo Barra]], a former Google executive who served Xiaomi's vice president from 2014 to 2017, characterized the organization as "an Internet and a software company much more than a hardware company".{{Cite book|title= Navigating the New Retail Landscape: A Guide for Business Leaders|last= Treadgold|first= Alan|last2= Reynolds|first2= Jonathan|publisher= Oxford University Press|year= 2016|isbn= 9780198745754|location= Oxford|pages= 128}} Xiaomi also keeps its prices low or close to [[bill of materials | "bill-of-material"]] by keeping most of its products in the market longer, eighteen months rather than the six-month norm followed by many smartphone companies. This strategy allows Xiaomi to take advantage of price reductions in the prices of key components of its products. It enables the company to sell hardware with specifications comparable to high-end devices at a fraction of the cost.{{Cite book|url= https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=SpjeBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1&dq=xiaomi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjj3tqv2MfcAhXGVLwKHQzOBkgQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=xiaomi&f=false|title= Xiaomi Patent Portfolio Analysis|last= |first= |date= 2014-10-01|publisher= LexInnova Technologies, LLC|year= |isbn= |location= |pages= 1|language= en}}{{qn|date=August 2018}} The company's version of the Android operating system, the MIUI [[Skin (computing) | skin]], with its design, [[app marketplace]], and functionalities, has established a community of users who form a crucial part of Xiaomi's customer base and contribute to the company's drive for market awareness. This ecosystem is a massive source of revenue as indicated in 2015, when sales from the platform reached $750 million.{{Cite book|title= Smartphone Start-ups: Navigating the iPhone Revolution|last= Giachetti|first= Claudio|publisher= Palgrave Macmillan|year= 2018|isbn= 9783319679723|location= Cham|pages =65}} The company focuses on India, the world's second-largest smartphone market{{Cite web|url= https://www.caixinglobal.com/2018-08-07/smartphone-upstart-xiaomi-brings-partner-to-india-to-curry-local-favor-101312616.html|title= Smartphone Upstart Xiaomi Brings Partner to India to Curry Local Favor - Caixin Global|website= www.caixinglobal.com|language= en|access-date= 2018-08-08}}{{Cite web|url= https://telecom.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/indian-smartphone-market-grows-23-to-overtake-us-in-q3-samsung-xiaomi-drive-shipments/61255184|title= Indian smartphone market grows 23% to overtake US in Q3; Samsung, Xiaomi drive shipments - ET Telecom|last= www.ETTelecom.com|website= ETTelecom.com|language= en|access-date= 2018-08-08}}. Xiaomi announced on May 2, 2018, the launch of Mi Music and Mi Video to offer "value-added internet services" in India{{Cite web|url= https://www.caixinglobal.com/2018-05-03/xiaomi-rolls-out-music-video-apps-in-india-101266004.html|title= Xiaomi Rolls Out Music, Video Apps in India - Caixin Global|website= www.caixinglobal.com|language= en|access-date= 2018-08-08}}. On March 22, 2017, Xiaomi announced that it planned to set up a second manufacturing unit in India in partnership with contract manufacturer Foxconn.{{Cite web|url= https://k.caixinglobal.com//web/detail_17183|title= Xiaomi to Partner with Foxconn to Open Second Factory in India|website= k.caixinglobal.com|language= en|access-date= 2018-08-08}}Compare: {{Cite web|url= http://www.eiu.com/industry/article/375310221/xiaomi-to-open-second-manufacturing-facility-in-india/2017-04-10|title= Xiaomi to open second manufacturing facility in India|last= Solutions|first= EIU Digital|website= www.eiu.com|access-date= 2018-08-08 | quote = Xiaomi Inc plans to set up a second manufacturing unit in India to cater to a growing demand for smartphones in the Asian country, according to media reports on March 22nd, citing a company announcement.}} On August 7, 2018, Xiaomi announced on its blog{{Cite web|url= http://blog.mi.com/en/2018/08/07/news-xiaomi-brings-smartphone-component-manufacturing-to-india-with-holitech-technology/|title= [News] Xiaomi brings smartphone component manufacturing to India with Holitech Technology – Mi Blog|website= blog.mi.com|language= en-US|access-date= 2018-08-08}} that Holitech Technology Co. Ltd., Xiaomi's top supplier, would invest up to $200 million over the next three years to set up a major new plant in India. {{Cite web |url= https://www.caixinglobal.com/2018-08-07/smartphone-upstart-xiaomi-brings-partner-to-india-to-curry-local-favor-101312616.html |title= Smartphone Upstart Xiaomi Brings Partner to India to Curry Local Favor - Caixin Global |website= www.caixinglobal.com|language= en|access-date= 2018-08-08 }} == Gallery == File:Xiaomi Mi Note Pro.jpg|Xiaomi Mi Note Pro File:Xiaomi Mi4.jpg|Xiaomi Mi 4 Smartphone File:Xiaomi Mi5.jpg|Xiaomi Mi 5 Smartphone File:MI 5 pic.jpg|Xiaomi MI 5 File:Xiaomi Yi Sport.jpg|Xiaomi Yi Sport Wearable Camera File:Xiaomi Powerbank.jpg|Xiaomi Power Bank File:Xiaomi Mi 5X.jpg|Xiaomi Mi 5X Phone File:Xiaomi Pocophone F1.jpg|[[Xiaomi Pocophone F1]] backside with dual camera == See also == * [[MIUI]] * [[Xiaomi Smart Home]] * [[YI Technology]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Xiaomi}} * {{Official website}} {{Xiaomi}} {{Electronics industry in China}} {{Major mobile device companies}} [[Category:Xiaomi| ]] [[Category:Electronics companies of China]] [[Category:Information technology companies of China]] [[Category:Mobile phone companies of China]] [[Category:Telecommunication equipment companies of China]] [[Category:Computer hardware companies]] [[Category:Home automation companies]] [[Category:Mobile phone manufacturers]] [[Category:Networking hardware companies]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in China]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Beijing]] [[Category:Electronics companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Chinese companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Chinese brands]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange]] [[Category:2018 initial public offerings]]
